#Text=Spot a Bad Contractor
#Text=When you 're planning on doing up , changing or fixing a part of your home or garden , it pays to know who is likely to do a good job for value .
#Text=And that means knowing who might be a bad bet as a contractor .
#Text=Many people have had a bad contractor experience .

#Text=These experiences come in all sorts of flavors , from bad workmanship to unfinished work to " unforeseen " cost over-runs , or in the worst case , the contractor skips town with your money and does no work .

column1: #Text=This article aims to point out the problem signs before you sign on the dotted line .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Be wary of a deal that 's too good to be true .
#Text=Watch out if the contractor in question 's bid was far below all of the others .

#Text=This is a sure sign that the contractor is either unfamiliar with the work in question ( and therefore also probably new to the work ) , or has underbid on purpose because he intends to have cost over-runs later .
#Text=Another play on this theme is if the contractor offers a great bargain in order to use " your project " as an example , such as featuring it on a website or in a brochure .
#Text=Ask for references .
#Text=Beware the contractor who has questionable or no references and or no fixed business address .
#Text=Always ask for references ; if the contractor does good work , he will have many , many examples of this through his references .
#Text=Any contractor that does not have a fixed business address could be a fly-by-night operation .
#Text=If you are suspicious of any address provided , turn up to see if it exists before you sign up .
#Text=Have a written agreement .
#Text=Be very cautious when the contractor does not want to go through the formalities of signing a contract .

#Text=When you are doing any major work , a contract that spells out what the scope of work is , and what the contractor 's responsibilities are , is standard business practice and any person who does not want to follow that is suspect .
#Text=Trust your gut instinct .
#Text=When you get a bad feeling , trust your gut feeling ; the guy who seems like a sleazy sales man probably is .
#Text=High pressure sales tactics such as " This price is only valid until I walk out of that door , you have to sign this right now ... " are a very bad sign .
#Text=If you feel hassled , pushed , intimidated or bullied , this is n't the contractor for you .
#Text=Seek another opinion .
#Text=Be very cautious of the contractor who uses scary scenarios to get you to buy more expensive options or more extensive work than what you initially wanted .
#Text=If problems are uncovered during a project , they should be obvious .
#Text=Like a doctor , you can always get a second opinion .
#Text=Do your own research .
#Text=Use the internet to learn as much as possible about the product or services that you want for your home or garden .

#Text=If you are fairly knowledgeable about the product or service , you will be familiar with the lingo , you will be able to ask pertinent questions , and it will be clear to the contractor that you know what you want and this will scare off a bad contractor or can lead them to say things that you know are wrong or poorly informed .
#Text=Ask people whose advice you value .
#Text=The best way to find a good contractor is to ask your friends , family or neighbors .
#Text=More often then not , they have used somebody with a good result .
#Text=Be extremely wary of the guy who pulls up in front of your house out of the blue and tells you that you need a new roof ( or something else ) .
#Text=Best to tell that person to be on his way .
#Text=Additionally , many locations require contractors to have licenses .
#Text=If you live in one of those locations , it is perfectly reasonable to ask for a copy of the contractors license and insurance certificate .
#Text=No show , no go .
#Text=Guard yourself against possible retaliation .
#Text=If you have fired a contractor who you provided a key to access your home , change your locks as soon as possible .
#Text=Best to leave temptation at the door rather than let it through .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If you feel that you have been ripped off , call the local authorities .
#Text=Blatant theft , such as a contractor took your money and left town , should be reported to the police .
#Text=Other situations may need to be handled through civil courts , The Better Business Bureau or other organizations .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Sighting of license or other professional standards documents
#Text=Contract
#Text=References , word-of-mouth
#Text=Examples/samples of work done elsewhere
#Text=Second opinions
#Text=( consider at least 2 or 3 contractors for any major home job )
